description.text: This is a small stand for holding Arduino Unos.  It has grooves to keep the Arduino off the ground and clips to hold it in place.

(1) Print using default replicator settings. For me, this is:

  • Object Infill: 10%

  • Layer Height: .27mm

  • Number of Shells: 1

  • Feedrate: 40mm/s

  • Travel Feedrate: 55mm/s
    • (2) I usually like to set the plate to 110 deg instead of 100. (3) Push your Arduino into the stand gently. I had to work at it a few times before I could get the board into the slots reliably, but with a little bit of practice it worked without any trouble. (4) To remove your Arduino, push the clips outward gently and pull your Arduino out

I made this a few years ago when I couldn't find a printable or well done Obi Wan lightsaber. I'm sure there's better ones now and I should've uploaded it long ago but here we are. I left it hollow in the center to hide an Arduino Mini, batteries, wiring, and some LEDs to make it light up. The knobs and buttons were supposed to be all functional but after Halloween (which is what I made it for) it just never got done.

I can't guarantee everything fits perfectly but they do with a little work as you can see from the assembled pics.

I apologize that's it's been so long since I've looked at this but I believe the files ending in 88 are simply scaled down to 88% of the size because the original model seemed a bit big to me.

If there's enough interest I might just upload the original (made in SketchUp) and someone could do more with this.

title: Mini Tool Rack for Mini Drawers Ultimate

description.text:
I love the Mini Drawers Ultimate tiny storage cabinets designed by zeropage (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1889761).

After printing a few, I wondered what else could attach using the interlocking system. A mini tool rack came to mind so I designed one using Tinkercad. It slides into the grooves on any of the "houses" from the Mini Drawers Ultimate.

It will hold a few hex wrenches, a small open end wrench and maybe a small screw driver.

title: DIY BARBIE MYOELECTRIC ARM
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Esta solución protésica solo se podrá adaptar en un paciente niño mayor a 3 años o adulto bajo la asesoría de una profesional de la salud, terapeuta, fisioterapeuta, fisiatra y con la colaboración de un profesional en psicología .
Por favor lea cuidadosamente primero el manual de seguridad y uso de esta solución protésica.
Prótesis DIY MYOELECTRIC ARM es un proyecto diseñado y elaborado por la fundación materialización 3D con la participación de Andrés Tolosa, Javier Garzón, John Bejarano y Cristina Acevedo. Modelo a su vez basado en el brazo Flexy, el Flexy_Hand 2 de Steve Wood (Gyrobot), el brazo RIT (Rochester Institute of Technology) el trabajo del grupo e_NABLE y la MyPO de PO Paraguay https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2409406. Trabajo desarrollado por el equipo e-Nable Colombia en la Fundación Materialización 3D http://materializacion3d.com/ en Bogotá. Todos estos archivos están cubiertos por la licencia creativa atribución bienes comunes. No comercial, por favor utilice la referencia de nosotros si desea imprimirlo.
Todos los padres y los niños fueron informados sobre el estudio e investigación para el desarrollo de este trabajo. Para niños de 3 a 16, el consentimiento fue explicado por el investigador principal y firmado por los niños y sus padres. El consentimiento informado por escrito de los padres se obtuvo con el fin de publicar las imágenes y vídeos que aparecen en el estudio de investigación y la investigación. Se les entregaron pautas de seguridad detalladas a los padres sobre el uso y cuidado de la prótesis de brazo.
pautas de seguridad detalladas enlace: http://enablingthefuture.org/build-a-hand/safety-guidelines/
Los dedos y las armellas están impresos en material Flexy, mano, antebrazo, brazo y demás partes en material PLA.
Para mas información sobre la Fundación Materialización 3D, E-Nable Colombia e E-Nable: https://www.facebook.com/materializacion3d/?fref=ts
Fundación Materialización 3D / Bogotá - Colombia

This prosthetic solution can only be adapted in a patient over 3 years old or an adult under ancillary to a health professional, therapist, physical therapist, physiatrist and with the help of a professional in psychology.
Please read the safety manual and use of this prosthetic solution carefully first.
DIY MYOELECTRIC ARM is a project designed and developed by 3D materialization foundation with the participation of Andrés Tolosa, Javier Garzón, John Bejarano and Cristina Acevedo. Model in turn based on the Flexy arm, the Flexy_Hand 2 Steve Wood (Gyrobot), arm RIT (Rochester Institute of Technology) e_NABLE work group and the MyPO by PO Paraguay https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2409406. Work developed by the team e-Nable Colombia and 3D materialization foundation in Bogotá http://materializacion3d.com/. All these files are covered by the common creative license attribution goods. Non-commercial, please use the reference to us if you want to print.
All parents and children were informed about the study and research for the development of this work. For children 3-16, consent was explained by the principal investigator and signed by the children and their parents. Written informed parental consent was obtained in order to publish the pictures and videos that appear in the research study and research. Parents were given detailed safety guidelines about the use and care of prosthetic arm.
detailed safety guidelines link: http://enablingthefuture.org/build-a-hand/safety-guidelines/
The fingers are printed on Flexy materials, hand, forearm, arm and other parts of PLA material.
For more information on 3D materialization, E-Nable Colombia and E-Nable Foundation:
https://www.facebook.com/materializacion3d/?fref=ts
Colombia - materialization 3D / Bogota Foundation

description.text: These frames are designed to fit the electronics & motors from a 'txJuice Pocket Drone'.

Pied de fixation configurable
“automatic translation”

Configurable mounting foot

Foot allowing fastenings by sheet or wood screws or metric pitch, positioning of the screws by the inside or the outside of the profile.
The foot has a rail at the top and bottom to accommodate different adapters:

adaptVis3.stl => sheet metal or wood screws with a minimum diameter of 3 mm
adaptVis4 .stl => same for screws with a minimum diameter of 4 mm
adapt_M3.stl => screw nut M3
adapt_M4.stl => screw nut M4

RondelleSup.stl => upper washers in the form of breakable bars.

The foot has a height of 50 mm, change the scale factor on the printing software to change this value.
///////////////////////
Pied de fixation configurable

Pied permettant des fixations par vis tôle ou bois ou pas métrique, positionnement des vis par l’intérieur ou l’extérieur du profil.
Le pied comporte un rail en partie supérieur et inférieur pour loger différents adaptateurs :

adaptVis3.stl => vis tôle ou bois de diamètre minimum de 3 mm
adaptVis4 .stl=> idem pour vis de diamètre minimum de 4 mm
adapt_M3.stl => vis écrou M3
adapt_M4.stl => vis écrou M4

RondelleSup.stl => rondelle supérieure sous forme de barrette sécable.

Le pied a une hauteur de 50 mm, changer le facteur d’échelle sur le logiciel d’impression pour changer cette valeur.

description.text:
This is an icon of the Earth Kingdom from Avatar the Last Airbender to be printed on a 3d printer. It could be used for a necklace, or a keychain. Whatever you like. The whole thing is 30mmx30mm with 3 mm high edges and the design is raised 1mm. If this is too low, let me know and I'll make one with larger raises.
UPDATE: The first version didn't print at all so I'm uploading a revised version which I can confirm prints. It's a bit small, so you may want to scale it. I'm also including the sketchup file for anyone who wants it.

This is the Autobot logo from the Transformers movies series by Micheal Bay. This fit on a 5cm by 5cm square with a total of three layers. The back plate has a height of .3cm, the highest extrusion being .7cm and all of the other features on the face have a .3cm height. This logo was made with a partner.

description.text:
This is an extruded piece of 2D art in the shape of the Disney logo before the start of each movie. It fits a 5.6 cm by 4.5 cm square.

There are 2 layers to this model: a flat backing plate where we can extrude the rest of the model from and a cut-extruded arc where the castle lies.

There is also some text at the bottom of the model.

Even though the Disney logos have changed over the years, the original logo that children would see before a movie is still remembered by many.

This was created with coordination and collaboration with my partner. Go check it out: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596764

Post printing note: I have recently printed this piece. I would recommend enlarging this piece by at least 150% because when the piece is on a smaller scale, the little details like the castle flags and other decorations tend to not print as nicely.
This is the image that I based my project off of.

Should have a flat back; detail will be on the front side
Should fit inside a box that is 25cm2 when lying flat
Should be no more than 1cm thick
Detail will be made using sketches that are extruded to different heights
Sketch must begin with a constraint box, (a center-rectangle created from the origin)
Dimensions should be detailed but efficient
Sketch must contain zero error messages
Sketch must be fully defined when complete
Demonstrate efficient use of “Construction Lines”/”Reference Geometry”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Offset Entities”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Manual Relations”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Smart Dimensions”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Mirroring”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Linear Patterns”

This is the Autobots logo from the Transformers Movie Series by Michael Bay. This will fit on a 5x5 cm square with a thickness of .7 cm. We had a total of 3 layers. The back plate has a height of .2 cm, the the highest extrusions being .7 cm and all other features of the face is .3 cm.

EDIT: The piece did come out very clean, however, there are small details on the piece, which can cause a problem when printing. I recommend enlarging this by at least 50% for the piece to come put clearer.

title: Nerf Rival Khaos Sling Mounting Hardware

description.text: I designed this to fit over a nerf khaos blaster. It matches the contours of the shoulder rest and requires the hole on the rest to be enlarged and made into a through hole to fit an m3 bolt. The m3 bolt is secured on the mount itself with an inserted locking nut.The front mount also uses an m3 bolt. For the sling interface, I took some existing hardware from an airsoft gun and bent it into the holes on the mount.

description.text:
This is the 2D-model of slime tabby from a game "Slime rancher". It fits on a 5x5 square. It features 3 layers. First, a backing plate, to hold the entire thing.The next layer has the general silhouette of the character, followed by a layer containing all the details of the character, including the face, highlights, stripes on the tail, the outline of the ears, and so on. Filet tool was used to smooth out me ost edges to give that smooth look. Slime Rancher is a fun game, you should give it a try.
In the final product shown it should be noted that some text (The initials, and the words 'Slime Rancher') are completely illegible. Printing these details in this smalls of a piece didn't come out as well. It's strongly recommended that you print at least 150% size to ensure smaller details are visible.

The 2D-3D model of the Disney Logo fits inside of a 5.6cm and 4.5cm construction block. The model is two layers, the first layer is the letters and the castle which were done by extrude cut, and then the towers were done by extrude, and extruded above the arc behind it. The words "Walt Disney" were done by downloading the Disney font, and then typing it and placing it on the model.
There are many tiny details that do not show up well with the dimensions it was made with, for the best results print it at 150%-200%. This should help make sure that some of the small details show up better.
The picture used to create the 2D art

Sketch 5.6 cm by 4.5 cm construction box.
Create the base plate roughly the shape of the logo.
Create a rectangle as wide as the base (height tbd)
Create two lines ? cm in from each end of the top of the rectangle.
Create an arc using those two lines with a point in the middle.
Make line that connects the rectangle to the arc a construction line. (From line to line).
Sketch the arch using the arch tool and the words using arcs and lines and offset entities by capping them with arcs to create the bubble like shape
Draw the arc in the building using the arc tool
Draw the rectangles for each layer of the castle and space them evenly using smart dimensions
Draw triangles at the top of each layer by using the three point rectangle and cut them in half to form the triangle
Extrude arch and letters by 0.5 cm
Extrude the castle another 0.5 cm on top of the arch and letters
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ayRTNiZiBfN

This is a 2D-3D model of the Hylian shield from the popular game "Zelda." It is a fairly complicated design due to the amount of arcs and small lines that give it better detail. All of these lines required several smart dimensions which made the design cluttered. The hardest part of the design by far was the construction of the head of the bird due to the coordination that was necessary between my partner and I.

"When you are wise, appear foolish." --Qie Zi, The Art of Seej There's a password to a secret Seej model hidden inside the data for the Cryptstone Oubliette Bloxen. The secret model isn't available on Thingiverse, and only those who break the code can find it. The doors to The Crypt stand covered in dust at http://crypt.s33j.net. Models lie beyond each of the doors. Stuck? Need a hint? Follow http://twitter.com/Zheng3_Jim and send me a direct message. Good luck with Cryptstone Challenge Secundus.

Construction is snap-together! Print one each of the base, plate, and ring, or just one copy of bloxen_oubliette_full.stl. The .zip file contains all the pieces you need. bloxen_oubliette_stego.stl will probably print, but no promises. That's the model in which you should look for the secret code. If your oft-churning cortex remains unfazed by this paltry hurdle, you can always try the Original Cryptstone Challenge: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24741 -=-=-] CopyPasta Seej Verbiage [-=-=- Seej is an Open Source tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://s33j.net for rules and more information. At a minimum, you'll need the Seej starter set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24013 Lots of players lurves them some ballista, too: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23464 You can also search Thingiverse for Things with the seej tag.

As so many others have done first, here is my rendition of the Lack Enclosure for my Monoprice Maker Select V2. This enclosure can be customized to fit many printers out there. The enclosed area is slightly larger than 17.5"W x 17.5"D x 15.5"H. I used a Dremel Tool to modify the Plexiglas walls and door to accommodate my spool holder (2nd picture), my printer controls, and a hole for my printer wires to exit the back of the enclosure. The power supply, printer controller, and my raspberry pi are mounted underneath the enclosure in a plastic bin (3rd picture).

PARTS LIST
Printed Parts
-Top_Back_Brackets.stl (2x)
-Top_Front_Left_Brackets.stl (1x)
-Top_Front_Right_Brackets.stl (1x)
-Bottom_Back_Brackets.stl (2x)
-Bottom_Front_Left_Brackets.stl (1x)
-Bottom_Front_Right_Brackets.stl (1x)
-Filament_Tube_without_Sensor.stl (1x)
-Door_Corner.stl (2x)
-Door_Handle.stl (1x)
-Thing: 1083876 (2x)

Purchased Parts
-Lack Side Tables (2x)
-Plexiglas - .118 thick cut to 15.5"x17.25" (4x)
-Screws - #8 x 3/4" (24-32x)
-Magnets 0.33"D x .125 thick (I found at Hobby Lobby) (4x)

NOTES:
-Magnets are inserted into the door corners (one in each of the 2) and the remaining two magnets are hot glued behind the corresponding door bumps.

-For my printer I removed the electronic components from the steel casing it came in (voiding any warranty I may have had) and mounted most of them underneath the enclosure, except the screen which is mounted in the door.
MORE DETAILS COMING SOON

-I also mounted a light inside the enclosure running a wire from my power supply (12V) to a switch i mounted on the left wall then running up to an Angel Eye.

author: fantom1951

description.text: FPV frame kit 220mm

IGES files NOW AVAILABLE! STEP files NOW AVAILABLE! This was a Mid-Coast to West-Coast collaborative effort with pcenginefx! (http://www.thingiverse.com/pcenginefx/designs). I did the CAD and he did the testing and photography. This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:228055 for REP2X. Made to fit a third 40mm fan for active cooling. The reason I originally designed this for our Replicator2X, is because I wanted to get air all around the nozzle while printing. Having air coming from just the front was not working well for my needs. Now Flash Forge owners can enjoy the same benefits! This design hugs a little closer to the extruder carriage than some other versions. Helpful for PLA and ABS prints.

This thing is designed to print at 0.2 layer height, 2 shells, and 15% fill, no raft or support. I had a little trouble with bridging over the ducts. My solution was to turn off bridging and change the solid layer angle to 90 degrees. Be sure to clean out any "spaghetti" in the air ways. The short fan-to-duct bolts are M3-10. (2 bolts, 2 nuts)
The long duct-to-extruder bolts that replace the original ones are M3-60.

Besides making awesome key chains, wave springs are very cool. It's easy to design your own. I did the tall one in Solidworks with the equation:
x = 1sin(t)
y = 1cos(t)
z = 0.125sin(3.5t)+0.075t
with
x(t) = radiussin(t) or radiuscos(t)
y(t) = radiuscos(t) or radiussin(t)
z(t) = amplitudesin(number wavest) + (if you want it to grow upwards) (spacingt)
The cross section is a rectangle.
I did the short one in Inventor with the Cylindrical equation:
r = 1
phi = t360
z = .25(sin (t360*5))
The cross section is a circle since Inventor is weak with controlling your sweeps. I guess at least that program lets me have a closed loop.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg1LRE0V7S4

This is the human enzyme DPP-4. Well, DPP-4 chewing on GLP-1 hormone. When you eat, cells in your intestine releases incretin hormones like GLP-1. GLP-1 stimulates the release of insulin from your pancreas and hinders the release of glucagon (which has the opposite effect of insulin, increasing the concentration of glucose in the blood). The incretins make sure that your blood glucose level is well regulated, however it is important that incretins like GLP-1 does not have a too long effect. This is where DPP-4 comes into play. DPP-4 is an amazingly beautiful enzyme on the surface of almost every cell in the human body. Deep inside this hollow peptidase, is the active site. GLP-1 can access the heart of DPP-4 through a perfect opening and when it does, exactly two amino acids are cleaved off the hormone, rendering it totally inactive.  
Included in the source files, you'll find the DPP-4 enzyme, the GLP-1 hormone and a split copy of DPP-4. Print it out and marvel at the beauty of nature and science.  
I work at the worlds largest producer of diabetes related drugs and in my team I'm responsible for an upcoming drug, that inhibits the effect of DPP-4 thereby increasing the effect of incretins. This drug will help MILLIONS of type-2 diabetes patients world wide. This structure is sitting next to my human insulin model on my desk.  
Monomer isolated from 2RGU pdb model.

DPP-4 (complete structure)
Supports are required and when I printed this with 0.3mm layer height, it took me 16h30m. The complete model requires a lot of postprint cleaning and the hollow structure is hard to clean out properly. DPP-4 (split model)
The split model requires supports and will have to be glued together. It is much easier to clean out post printing, but you'll have to make due with a glued seam. However, the split model i way faster to print than the complete model.
Hmm I'm having problems making the two halves fitting together. I can't see any problem with the model, so it might be my print. Consider yourselves warned ;) GLP-1
This is a tiny model, but still requires supports. Theses are easily removed and due to the tiny structure, you can print it with 0.1mm layer height and be done quickly. General remarks
I've printed the complete DPP-4 structure with a 0.3 mm layer height and with supports with 2 interface layers. My models were sliced in Slic3r and printed in PLA on my Reprappro Mendel Mono.

It is comprised of 4 layers. The first layer is the inset stars at 0.2 cm. The second layer is the entire model except for the stars. The third layer is the letters and the body of both penguins at 0.4cm. The fourth layer is the wings of the small penguin and the head of Tux which lay at 0.5cm.

description.text:
We decided to create a simplified version of the city crest of Hamburg. This is a 2D-3D model that fits on a 10cm by 10cm square. We extruded the model 10 times by; extruding both of the stars, the door, the door rim, the base of the castle, the medium crenelations, the top crenelations, the 2 outer towers, the middle tower, the middle battlements, and the dome on the middle tower. We have have 7 layers.

When I printed this I think it came out rather feel compared to some of the other ones in the class because the ones that didn't have a smooth back didn't come out as well. Also most of the 3D models with words and/or letters didn't come out so good because it was printed so small the words got mushed together which ultimately ruined the model. For the best results I would recommend printing this at 2x size because when we compared a smaller 3D model and a bigger 3D model of the same design the bigger model came out a lot better.
Model is based off this picture.

Outline
Make a reference box 4.297 cm by 5.818 cm, with the bottom right corner at the origin.
Make a reference line down the center.
Make a rectangle with the same dimensions as the reference box, in the same place.
Make a circle, centered on the center line, tangent to the bottom and both sides of the reverence box.
Use trim entities to trim the solid lines of the bottom corners outside the circle, and the circumference of the circle inside the rectangle. Door
Make a vertical line 0.7 cm to the left of the center line 1.5 cm long.
Make an arc 90 degrees from the top of the line to the center line.
Offset both entities to left a distance of 0.1 cm.
Make a line from the end of the arc to the bottom of the center line.
Castle Crenelations
Make a horizontal reference line from the center points of both sides of the reference box, Midline.
Offset the Midline vertically up 0.25 cm, the crenelations line.
Mirror the crenelations line across the Midline, Crenelations Prime.
Make a vertical line from the Midline up to the Crenelations Line, smart dimensioned to 0.15 cm from the Center/Mirror line.
Make a line from the top of the previous line to the intersection of the crenelation line and the Center Line.
Mirror bothe lines across Center Line to form the first crenelation.
Linear pattern the crenelations 3 times to the left, 0.6 cm displaced.
Make lines connecting the bottom corners of the crenelations.
Make a vertical line down from the bottom of the last crenelation on the left to Crenelations Prime line.
Make a horizontal line along the prime line from the end of the last line to the center line. Side Tower
Make a horizontal reference line halfway between the Midline and the top of the reference box.
Make a center rectangle, tower box, 0.9 cm wide, with:
the left side bisecting the top of the last crenelations,
The top along the aforementioned reference line,
The bottom on the Midline
Make a construction box centered on the midpoint of the top of the tower box, the right side in line with the third crenelation from the left., the battlement box, height ___
Make real lines along the bottom and both sides of said box
Make a real line along the right side of the tower box from the top of the crenelation to the top left corner of the box.
Make a line from the intersection of the right side of the tower box and the battlement box to the point where it intersects the crenelations*
Make a line extending the left edge of the battlement box up, an equal length to the side of the battlement box
Make a line perpendicular to the previous line, of an equal length
Make a line going down from the end of the last line, an equal length
Make a vertical construction line from the center of the battlement box to the top of the reference box
Mirror the entities made in steps 7-9 across the aforementioned line Middle Tower
Use a linear sketch pattern to create 2 more rectangles exactly like the leftmost one.
Smart Dimension it exactly like the lefthand most one but without the crenellations.
Make a semi circle on top of the rectangle.
Smart Dimension it to
Measure up ____ and place a point
Make 2 construction center rectangles overlapping each other, one horizontal and one vertical with the point their midpoint
Outline them with real lines left of the Middle lines
Trim the bottom edge of the vertical rectangle
Make a 2 point arc to form the incomplete semi circle. Stars Only make the lefthand most one then mirror it across the y axis.
Measure up ------ cm and place a point this will be the bottom vertical of the 6 point star.
Then measure up and place a point exactly above the first for the top vertical of the star.
Then make 4 more points 1 for each of the verticals.
Then make 6 more points for the parts where it angles in.
Connect the points with lines.

This is a 2D-3D model of a simplified version of the city crest of Hamburg, Germany. It fits in a 4.297 cm by 5.818 cm.
The model has 7 layers. The background is the least extruded layer. The castle body and the three towers are all on the same layer. The door is slightly depressed from the castle, and its frame is slightly elevated. Main crenelations are on one layer, and the three smaller sets of crenelations are on another. The dome and the stars are the last layer.

When it was printed, various small problems occurred, so it is recommended that This piece be printed at least 150% size

Made in collaboration with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596933

You and your partner will have the same design which meets the constraints below, and you will EACH use Solidworks to create your design. Constraints: Should have a flat back; detail will be on the front side
Should fit inside a box that is 25cm2 when lying flat
Should be no more than 1cm thick
Detail will be made using sketches that are extruded to different heights
Sketch must begin with a constraint box, (a center-rectangle created from the origin)
Dimensions should be detailed but efficient
Sketch must contain zero error messages
Sketch must be fully defined when complete
Demonstrate efficient use of “Construction Lines”/”Reference Geometry”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Offset Entities”
Demonstrate efficient use of “Manual Relations”

Demonstrate efficient use of “Mirroring”

Each group will make a single front view sketch of your piece. Dimensions should be clearly labeled and should match your final Solidworks drawing. You may make these and edit them as you go, but you must keep track of them all.
A bulleted/numbered list of the order you will create your model to be updated as you work through completing your design. This plan MUST be approved before you begin making your figure in Solidworks.
Once you begin creating your models, you and your partner MUST work together, staying at the same pace. DO NOT move on to the next step of your plan until you’ve checked in with your partner and you are BOTH ready to proceed to the next step.

This is the logo of Metroid Prime, a Nintendo game. This logo is 5 cm by 4.5 cm. It has six layers. The first layer is the outer circle, at .1 cm tall. Next there is a thin circle that is .2 cm tall, and finally, an inner circle .3 cm tall. There are lines from the center of the circle that were extruded .075 cm tall, and the "S" in the center is .75 cm tall. Next, the "S" was extruded to .75 cm tall, and finally, the letters were extruded inwards. To make all of the details clearer than they are in the pictures, it is suggested to blow up the size 100-200%

I was reading through some of the forums and discussions regarding different ways to build PCBs. I started thinking about the midway point and had the idea to build a breadboard. I ran up a quick block of 20 rows (no power rails for this test). I've left a Slot under each row 10mm deep this is where a strip of metal is put in to form the contact. This is an experiment I intend to print when I have a bot. Primary design concerns are:
  • Will it print cleanly enough for use?
  • Has enough space been left for the metal contact strip?
  • What strip type would work best?
    • I've included the SKP file. NOTE: IF this works, selecting metal strips out of metal that will take solder would mean that the board could be turned over and components soldered into it to make it permanent. And then you could just print another one!

This design is untested:
Print it out and cut some strips of tin or metal about 10mm wide and 14mm long.
I imagine soda can metal would work well but be sure to sand it gently to make sure it will form a contact.
Curve the strips gently around a pencil (not too much because they still have to slide into the 1.4mm wide gaps - the curve should make the strip "grip" as it slides in).
Put the strips into the gaps underneath.
Use a drop of glue to hold the strips in place if needed
Turn over and use :)

comments.text: Could possibly have slits so that you can just slide in the contacts without having to use another material to keep it there.

title: SQ11 Mini DV camera mount clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my first attempt to upload one of my sketches on thingiverse. I got my SQ11 mini camera without the mounting clip and I thought to design a replacement based on photos of the actual one and precise measurements with a caliper.

There is a 2mm hole for a M2 screw but I will definitely add a GoPro type mounting in a future revision. It is ideal for those who don't like the heavy full-body mounts that are already available on thingiverse! It is lightweight and it holds the camera well, although I haven't tested it under intense usage (biking, drones etc.). Of course, with your ideas and modifications would be perfect! So feel free to mix!

I used Simplify3D to print and Autodesk Inventor Professional 2016 for the design process. Simplify3D didn't add support material at the four mounting edges and it came quite good. However, it needed some corrections with the x-acto knife and sandpaper 280. I hope you like it!

Note: My printer is a Prusa clone which I built by myself buying the materials one by one and combining 3D designs for the parts from various sources with trial and error. I am still calibrating the machine and thus the printing is not of the best quality (it's good though)!

title: Levelsensor device for saltcontainer of a water softener.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Every water softener like our "Seduction 16L Fleck" has a salt container, the salt is used for regeneration of the resincylinder. So, you need to check the level of the salt container on a regular basis and add salt if needed.. Easy to do: just open the lid of the container and look.
But why not improve the system a bit?

I made a salt level sensor for it: it has a RGB-led which gives 4 colors with the following meaning:

  • green=level ok
  • blue=level ok but add some salt in a few days.
  • red=level low, add salt
  • white=level out of range

But this is not all ofcourse, the sensor works also with the domotics software from http://domoticz.com/ and https://www.mysensors.org/.
So, you can monitor the salt level with your domotics system too!

Details about the sensor

  • Powersupply 24Volt AC, about 150mA.
  • You can use a 24Volt AC adapter, but don't use the 24Volt AC adapter of your softener: it has too less current. I have replaced my own adapter for an oversized adapter (1A) and placed a 800mA FUSE inside too (there was no fuse inside at all). I made a power splitter cable too, the new adapter feeds the softener and the sensor together,,
  • All details are in the files, domoticz history screendump and arduino script added too.

You need the following parts:

  • Arduino uno (remove the powerconnector, solder the wires of the outputs of the stepdown converter to the correct + and - poles.
  • NRF24L01
  • Optional: NRF24L01 adapter: with this you can feed 5Volt instead of 3.3Volt to the NRF.
  • Stepdown converter (change the output voltage to 9Volts.
  • AC-to-DC bridge
  • Ultrasoon sensor
  • RGB-led (common ground)
  • Powerplug 3.5mm
  • Resistors: 1x 100 ohm (Red pin), 2x 470 ohm (Green and Blue pins)
  • Bolts 3M (10 mm) and more

By the way, the sensor can be used standalone, so without domotics system, and the sensor can be used on all kind of water softeners ofcourse.

title: Under-desk mount for Ikea Alexa add-on's drawer

description.text:
I had an additional drawer from Ikea's Alexa add-on unit (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20260718/) and I wanted to mount the drawer underneath my standing desk. Hence I designed a bracket that made use of the drawer's existing rails and mounting it to the bottom of the desk using pocket holes.

To mount this, you will need the following parts from original packaging:

  • the drawer (fully assembled)
  • the two rails
  • the two screws holding the rails to the drawer
  • the four screws meant to be screwed onto the two brackets

You will need an additional 10 self-tapping #8 wood screws with the appropriate length (that it does not puncture your table top). Although I realised after mounting it that 10 pieces of screw is probably overkill...

You are free to edit the part for your own purpose (reduce the number of screws required, change the screw size, etc.) here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/1f96b421e06c35b3d578bf0e/w/7507773369343cc258fb837e/e/58afe146bcedd0464f47b610

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the part with 7 walls, 4 bottom layers and 8 top layers. I wanted the perimeters to be very sturdy especially since the pocket holes are meant to hold the angle of the screw firmly while it is being drilled into the wood.

The print took 13.5 hours to complete. A time lapse of the print can be found here: https://youtu.be/66-bkin-CJg

ATTENTION:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,15 mm

Infill:

20 - 50 % as you like

Notes:

I printed it in black PETG and it came out nicely. There was some stringing but i just used a hot air gun to get rid of it.

You have to print the cable clamp twice.

ATTENTION:

  • Make sure that you use a non-conductive Filament.
  • No graphit or carbonfibre filled filament.
  • Make sure to connect the protective conductor.
  • Do not do any electrical work if you are not a trained professional!

Be careful before turning in the screws. Depending on you printer/settings you can experience a hole to small. If you need to much force i recommend to use a drill and widen the holes a bit. A rule of thump says to have a hole with a diameter of 0,7 the diameter of the screw.

All dimensions are in mm!

Meanwell EPS 25 to lower part:
Use 4 pieces of 3,5x9,5 to fix the Meanwell board to the lower part.

Cable clamp to lower part:
Use 2 pieces of 3,5x9,5 to fix one cable clam to the lower part. Do this twice.

Upper part to lower part:
It is required to bring in a M4 thread in the lower part for 4 times.
You need some M4 x 40 screws to fix the upper to the lower part.

DIN rail adapter to lower part:
Use 4 pieces of 3,5x9,5 to fix every part of the DIN rail adapter to the lower part.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
I ran across Antscran's i3 platform spring cups (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1374667) and wanted to print a set for my latest model Duplicator i3 Plus.

The new i3 Plus's come with a 3mm nylock nut under the heat plate holding the screw on and isolation washer in place. The spring seats around the outside of this nut. Instead of taking the M3 nut off and placing it under the up, I redesigned the Top Cup to fit around the nut but still capture the lip of the spring within the seat of the cup.

You will need to print 4 upper cups and 4 of the original cups by Antscran to create a full spring cage. This works really well. and due to the additional ~2mm taken up by the cups themselves it creates a very stiff, but still adjustable build plate.

I used a washer under the bottom cup between the cup and the Y-Plate as well.

title: Eachine EV100 Receiver Case Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's my Eachine Pro58 Receiver Case for the Eachine EV100.

I was inspired to do this because of the mod video of "Drone Mesh", thanks man for the nice mod vid, how to solder in the receiver. Worked great for me.
https://youtu.be/n79b-z6n_Dk

The receiver is upside down but for me it doesn't matter and so you can control it from the right side and the cables can be attached easier.

I fixed the case with Tesa Powerbond Ultra Strong, which seem to do the job.
I only drilled a hole to get the cables from the FPV google into the receiver case.

You have to be sure that your cables are long enough to get connected to the receiver.

It took me 6 iterations to get the curve of the google good enough and to have the holes at the right position for the antenna and control wheel.

Hope you like it.

Designed to print fast and dirty. I print at 0.4mm layer height, 100 mm/s 3 shells and 3 top and bottom layers.

Designed for pla.

If anyone wants a smaller outer diameter, let me know. This is 150mm.

Added 115 mm diameter spools: 16 grams and an hour at my print speed.
Same print settings. Pretty sure these will fit almost every printer out there :-)
80mm centre, so even the stiff filaments will wrap fairly easily.

One tip: Spool fairly tight and once you've spooled the fialment, leave it for a week or so and it will adapt to the new shape and not spring all over the place when you try and use it.

description.text:
Parts you'll need:
Center x1 (4 pieces in stl)
center pin x1 (split into halves in stl)
Corner x10

Tools you'll need:
Super Glue
File
Flat cutters/Diagonal cutters
something long and rigid (i used the end of my file)

Directions:
Glue each half of the center together and file away any excess flashing. Make sure the halves are lined up perfectly, or the puzzle wont turn properly.

Glue Center pin together and file away until it can turn freely inside the smaller center piece. As well as fit into the hole on the larger center piece. Then insert pin through the hole on the small center piece.

Clean up corner pieces and insert 2 at a time into each center piece until full.

Put glue inside hole on inside of larger center piece in a way where it wont spill out. Push pieces together until dry, pushing the pin in.

Sticker, paint and enjoy

title: Pentagon Lithophane Base for G4 Bulb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed a 5 sided lithophane, each side with a pic of one of my children. I needed a way to display and light it. I whipped up this design. It's designed to allow you to install a G4 light socket, and light it with a G4 led bulb. Linked below are the socket I used and appropriate bulbs.

The skirt is intended to provide a lip to retain the lithophone. I made this part separate from the base, so that a large amount of support material is not required.

Socket:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JE9QHRS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

12v Bulb:
https://www.amazon.com/KINGSO-48%C3%973014-Equivalent-Silicone-Shatterproof/dp/B00UAALVM6/ref=sr_1_4?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1508529270&sr=1-4&keywords=g4+led+bulb

I'm not fully satisfied with this design, and am working on one that will rotate... I may post that one later.

Printer:

FT-5

Resolution:

.32

Infill:

15%

Slide skirt onto the top of the base, screw on the bottom cover.

If you choose to light yours, it's up to you to do so safely. I will not provide any specific instructions on this, as if you need instructions, you should not be doing this project. I use a 110 v bulb, so that I didn't need to purchase a power adapter for it. You can also get the bulbs in a 12v version, which is much safer to work with, and I would recommend going that route, and purchasing an appropriate 12v adapter for a few dollars.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/KjEhO3QDJds

EN

22.1.2018 I added a file (Robot.kwl), it is configuration file for android app.

I modified and designed a robot what looks like robots for bomb disposal (for ex. TALON-2). It´s only Arduino toy, what is controlled via bluetooth. However, all is full working, the machine has fully functional 5-axis robotic arm, robotic head, what can turn 360 degrees, it has laser, ultrasonic module, led light, FPV camera with automatic night vision IR.

I used this design during construction of robot body: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064087, but it´s quite a lot modified, all the body center is my own proposal, the same using 4 motors instead of 2. I used this design during construction of robotic arm: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015238

The motors are controlled by L298N Dual H-bridge with pwm input. Control unit is Arduino Uno with bluetooth module. I use the great application for android for robot controlling: http://www.keuwl.com/apps/bluetoothelectronics/

I wrote the arduino program for this project, it is not a perfect, but it works. If somebody wants, he can change the program and send me .ino file and I can publish it.

Parts list:
1x arduino uno: https://www.banggood.com/UNO-R3-ATmega328P-Development-Board-For-Arduino-No-Cable-p-964163.html?rmmds=search

1x arduino bluetooth module HC-06 : https://www.banggood.com/HC-06-Wireless-Bluetooth-Transceiver-RF-Main-Module-Serial-For-Arduino-p-80364.html?rmmds=search

4x arduino motor with gear: https://www.banggood.com/5Pcs-DC-3V-6V-Dual-Axis-Gear-Reducer-Motor-For-Arduino-Smart-Car-p-949555.html?rmmds=search

1x L298N motor driver: https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-Dual-H-Bridge-DC-Stepper-Motor-Drive-Controller-Board-Module-Arduino-L298N-p-42826.html?rmmds=search

6x micro servo MG90S: https://www.banggood.com/6X-Towerpro-MG90S-Metal-Gear-RC-Micro-Servo-p-1072260.html?rmmds=search

1x arduino ultrasonic module HC-SR04: https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-Ultrasonic-Module-HC-SR04-Distance-Measuring-Ranging-Transducer-Sensor-p-40313.html?rmmds=myorder

1x arduino laser module: https://www.banggood.com/KY008-Laser-Transmitter-Module-For-Arduino-AVR-PIC-p-931238.html?rmmds=search

2x DC-DC converter: https://www.banggood.com/3Pcs-5A-XL4005-DC-DC-Adjustable-Step-Down-Module-Power-Supply-Converter-p-1031856.html?rmmds=search

1x FPV transmitter: https://www.banggood.com/TS5828L-Micro-5_8G-600mW-40CH-Mini-FPV-Transmitter-with-Digital-Display-p-1058136.html?rmmds=search

1x packaging M3BN1 M3*4mm H62 Brass Knurl Nuts: https://www.banggood.com/100pcs-M34mm-H62-Brass-Knurl-Nuts-DIY-Accessories-p-971077.html?rmmds=myorder
1x eachine FPV receiver for Android: https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-ROTG01-UVC-OTG-5_8G-150CH-Full-Channel-FPV-Receiver-For-Android-Mobile-Phone-Smartphone-p-1147692.html?rmmds=search

Next you will need some old security cam or FPV cam: https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-1000TVL-13-CCD-110-Degree-2_8mm-Lens-Mini-FPV-Camera-NTSC-PAL-Switchable-p-1053340.html?rmmds=search

cz

22.1.2018 jsem přidal konfigurační soubor (Robot.kwl) pro nastavení android aplikace.

Upravil a navrhl jsem robota, který se velice podobá robotům na zneškodňování bomb jako je např. TALON-2. Je to pouze Arduino hračka, která se ovládá přes bluetooth, ovšem vše je plně funkční, stroj má 5-ti osou funkční robotickou ruku, robotickou sestavu hlavy, která se umí otočit o 360°, je vybavena laserem, sonarem, led přísvitem s čočkou, Fpv kamerou a automaticky spouštícím se infrapřísvitem (má noční vidění).

Při stavbě těla robota jsem vycházel z tohoto návrhu: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064087 ovšem je poměrně dost upravený, celý střed těla je podle vlastního návrhu stejně tak jako úprava na 4 motory namísto dvou. Při stavbě robotické ruky jsem vycházel z tohoto návrhu: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015238

Motory ovládá L298N dvoukanálový DC můstek ovládaný pwm vstupy. Srdcem robota je Arduino Uno s bluetooth modulem. Používám vynikající aplikaci pro android na ovládání robota: http://www.keuwl.com/apps/bluetoothelectronics/

K tomuto projektu jsem napsal program do Arduina, který ovšem není dokonalý, ale je plně funkční. Pokud někdo bude chtít, může program upravit a poslat mi .ino soubor a já jej zde zveřejním.

Seznam dílů:

6x micro servo MG90S: https://www.banggood.com/6X-Towerpro-MG90S-Metal-Gear-RC-Micro-Servo-p-1072260.html?rmmds=search

1x arduino sonar HC-SR04: https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-Ultrasonic-Module-HC-SR04-Distance-Measuring-Ranging-Transducer-Sensor-p-40313.html?rmmds=myorder

1x arduino laser modul: https://www.banggood.com/KY008-Laser-Transmitter-Module-For-Arduino-AVR-PIC-p-931238.html?rmmds=search

title: K8200 Extra Z axis nut holder

description.text:
I wanted an extra Z axis for my printer because I noticed that the arm with the extruder on is flexes easily up and down a bit. I had to file the part a little to make it a tight fit.
Probably had to do that because i haven't calibrated my printer yet to print the correct sizes.

I used solid edge to design the part, part files are also here to download.
This is for a 22 mm nut. The motor holder and the to axis holder can be found here elsewhere.
I made alu brackets for those. To mount the bracket you don't have to disassemble anything because it is a 2 part bracket. You need to tap the holes with M5 threads. Make sure that you mirror one of the brackets before printing. Have fun.

author: stimpy

title: NES Micro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Currently a work in progress. I have yet to print and test these models as the project is still in the design phase. Also included a model of the NES cart I made to check clearances.

So I'll admit I've been terrible about finishing projects. When I started college I told myself that I would put my larger projects on hold till I graduated. Then when I started grad school I did the same. Now most of those projects are sitting in a box collecting dust and I feel really bad that they never got to see their full potential. So I'm now going back and doing these projects justice.

I've collected the ashes of the Nintoaster project based around the NES side of the retro duo that I barely started before it was canned. It will be reborn into a more useful micro portable (no LCD but AV out) battery powered (with built in remaining capacity meter) NES that I can easily thow in a bag, take anywhere, and hook up to a pico projector for anywhere gaming. Because of this newfound life I will be dubbing this project NES Micro!

In this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=br5apIuwg6k) I show the pcb as it was before I stopped working on it and explain the concept and case design for the NES Micro. I'm really feeling this project so I even went as far as to do a super accurate model of the NES cart to check clearances. In the next video I'll 3D print the parts, start assembly, and design the electronics/firmware for the power and battery meter portions.

UPDATE: Added v1.0 of Eagle PCB design/gerber files

More details, firmware, etc will be made available in the future when completed.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/br5apIuwg6k" ></iframe>

title: Aomway TX001 VTX Holder - FPV Racing

description.text:
This part was made as I was sick of having my VTX, which is an Aomway TX001, ziptied to my top plate where it is susceptible to damage and in the way of my lipo straps. So I designed and printed this enclosure which made it possible to zip-tie it to my bottom plate in a nice and tidy space where I can still reach the buttons.

The design is made to slide down on M3x35mm standoffs. It is a tight fit on these standoffs and so it is nice and snug once you have it installed.

v1.1 Update: I thickened the walls in order for them to last longer as they were too thing in the previous version. Also made it longer and moved the the box down farther in order to allow easier manipulation of the wire plugs.

print_settings.Notes:: Printing a single part without the raft works, but I needed 80 parts (I use one at the top and another at the bottom of each stake). Building 16 without the raft I had several break loose in the print process, so I only got about 8 that were usable. With the raft, I was able to print 36 at a time (with room to add more). With the speed settings we use, the 36 part print with a 5 layer raft took 14 hours. I used Matter Control to easily mirror and make many copies of the part in a single STL.

description.text:
I am growing plants over a period of weeks to examine the effect of light duration on the rate of plant growth. To do this, I have 8 lima bean plants for each target duration. To help them grow straight and make them easy to measure, I want to place a stake next to each, and a ruler running up the stake. To make it easy to connect a 1x2 board to the stakes and the stakes to the rulers, I designed and printed the mount. The design has:

  • Corner guide to mount on the top of the board
  • Hole for a sheetrock screw to attach the mount to the board
  • Hole to place the stake through
  • Guide slot next to the stake hole to place the ruler in

I am sharing this to help others who might want to replicate my experiment or perform a similar plant growth experiment. Please share the uses you find for this part.

Robo 3D

Notes:

Printing a single part without the raft works, but I needed 80 parts (I use one at the top and another at the bottom of each stake). Building 16 without the raft I had several break loose in the print process, so I only got about 8 that were usable. With the raft, I was able to print 36 at a time (with room to add more). With the speed settings we use, the 36 part print with a 5 layer raft took 14 hours. I used Matter Control to easily mirror and make many copies of the part in a single STL.

A butterfly headphone cord wrapper. Designed in TinkerCAD to sell at a school craft fair.

Teal Sport Remix Challenge:
The Teal Sport is an 85mph FPV (First person view) racing/freestyle drone built with most of the best components available on the market today. The main thing that sets the Teal Sport apart from typical custom built race drones is the quick-swap modular body design. We believe this feature is an untapped platform for modification. The goal of this contest is to inspire the the 3D printing community to modify the Teal Sport's top cover aesthetics and utility. STEP and STL files of a plain top cover have been provided as a platform to get you started.

Measurements for all of the most popular FPV cameras are available on their manufacturer's websites. comments.author: kaptaink_cg

comments.text: Oh, I completely understand and agree with that. My concern was with conflicting with the existing hardware.  I've searched the Teal website but haven't been able to find any information on what the board/components look like when they cover is removed.  For example, is the jack for the antenna at a low tolerance location, or is there enough room to design with freedom?  Are the camera and its support completely removable?
comments.author: TealDrones

comments.text: The Camera, FPV video transmitter unit and antenna are only mounted to the top cover. They are attached with one removable plug to the main flight board. The FPV components do not extend below the bottom plane of the top cover. The flight control components do not extend above the top plane of the main chassis. The exploded view diagram above shows most of this, but please let us know if you have any more questions about fit.

No matter what, we're glad you're participating.

author: booboo59

title: Experimental Iphone 6 Nodal Point Adapter for Spherical Panorama with 1/4" Tripod Screw Support

description.text:
This is mainly a concept for an nodal point adapter for iphone 6.
It hasn't been tested at the moment and it's just for fun.

The Iphone 6 should be able to rotate horizontaly by just rotate the lower part of the adapter. Vertical rotations are made by untighten the screws and tighten them at an specific angle. There are also markings every 30 degrees.

Some parts are meant to be glued together after print for witch I would recommend superglue, witch should be used carefully.
Movable parts are designed with a space of 0.1mm.

I give no warranty for functionality or safety, it's just experimental.

There are no printsettings although the parts are rotated as they should be printed and some need some minor support. Some parts are used twice. For the parts with a screw I would recommend a layer height of 0.06mm.

Notes:

Parts that are used twice:
IP6_NPA_Schraube.stl
IP6_NPA_Ständer.stl

Parts with Screw:
IP6_NPA_Stativgewinde.stl
IP6_NPA_Schraube.stl

Support for:
IP6_NPA_Drehteller.stl
IP6_NPA_BefestigungL.stl
IP6_NPA_BefestigungR.stl

To be glued together:

1:
IP6_NPA_Handyhalterung
IP6_NPA_BefestigungL
IP6_NPA_BefestigungR

2:
IP6_NPA_Drehteller
IP6_NPA_Ständer (2x, one is rotated 180° on z-axis - the index markings should be one the inside)
For the Design I used Blender and Caliper.

author: Bluebone

description.text:
This is a modification of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912996. Because this bowl has a screw-on top I had to change the shape to circular. I also increased the diameter a bit so it would hold more stuff. The thread is a single helix, so to attach the top you have to have it lined up properly with the bottom. I am going to see if attaching the top is easier if the threads are a double or triple helix.

The top does print OK with no internal supports. With a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 100 mm/sec the top printed in just under 11 hours, and the bottom in 27 3/4 hours.
I finished the flower pot with my friend. I love schnauzers. In the future I plan to print and use for growing dionea

This mod is for the SeeMeCNC H-1 and is a complete redesign of the X-Carriage using PLA bushings and a Quick-Fit adaptor. A Quick-Fit support has also been designed for Steve's Extruder. This support is also designed for Budaschnozzle 1.0 but can be easily adapted for other hotends. A video of this things installed is available here : http://youtu.be/DFIuspUwfxo

You'll need :
  • PTFE 6.45mm OD/3.5 ID tubing (30 mm needed),
  • 40mm regular fan,
  • 40mm caseless graphic card fan (with provided M2 screws),
  • 70mm LED ring,
  • 4 copies of the provided PLA linear bushings,
  • 4x 40mm M4 screw with regular nuts,
  • 4x 25mm M3 screw with nylon lock nuts,
  • 2x 624ZZ bearings,
  • hot temp silicone,
  • cyanocrylate super glue.
    • Print the provided bushings with PLA.
    Print all the other parts with ABS. Enlarge/finish holes with a drill if necessary :
  • for the filament guide that will get the PTFE tubing (6.5mm drill),
  • for the fan duct screw holes (4.5mm drill),
  • for the quick-fit support holes that holds steve's extruder (4.5mm drill),
  • for the quick-fit support holes for fixing the budaschnozzle (3.5mm drill),
  • for the x-carriage assembly holes (3.5mm drill)
    • Tap with M4 tap the holes on the quick-fit support that will holds the fand duct. Glue the LED ring on the fan duct with hot temp silicone.
    Glue the 40mm fan holder to the back of the fan duct. Push your fan in the holder. Glue together par 1 and 2 of the side fan using super glue. Screw the caseless 40mm fan to the enclosure. Push the top after properly guide the power cord in the dedicated hole. Glue with super glue the PTFE tubing in the filament guide of the quick-fit support. Fix the budaschnozzle to the bottom of the support after guiding the cables to the dedicated holes. Assemble the X-Carriage with M3 screws. Push-in the PLA linear bushings.
    Put the 624ZZ bearing in the bird nose and X-Carriage and fix it with M4 screw. Install the X-Carriage to the H-1. Install the side fan. Install the steve extruder to the support. Because there is not so much space, you'll have to make a gentle rotation to insert the steve extruder support to the X-Carriage quick-fit support. Turn the bird nose to tight the assembly. Install the fanduct with M4 screws. Manage your cables !

This is a sword from the new movie Sword Art Online: Ordinal Scale. This is Asuna's sword. I cut this sword to fit any printer that can handle 100mm in Z height. If you have suggestions for other swords or weapons from Sci-fi and Anime, DM me and I'll consider it. If you print this model, please post a MAKE, I'd love to see it. Happy Printing!

Approximately 42in long when assembled.

PLEASE READ PRINT INSTRUCTIONS BELOW.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

.2

25%

Notes:

Two versions of the guard are available here. one is fully 3d printable, and one is designed to use a 150mmx3mm steel linear rod for added strength. Parts that end with " for 3mm rod" should only be printed if you intend to use the steel rod.

Steel rod for reference
https://www.amazon.com/10Pcs-Stainless-Steel-Cylinder-Linear/dp/B00JR56KI0/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1509732239&sr=8-1&keywords=3mm+rod

Test fit all components before final assembly. All pieces can be individually printed in their desired color.

Print one of each piece except what is stated below.
3 x Alignment Pin Small
5 x Alignment Pin Med

I always recommend printing alignment pins at 100% infill and laying flat on the build plate.

The three small alignment pins attach the front three pieces of the sword blade. The five medium alignment pins attach the remainder of the sword blade. The large alignment pin attaches the sword blade to the handle through the guard.

author: kalix_

description.text: Trying to build a dust shoe / accessory holder for MPCNC. Wanted it to be attached to the gantry and not the Z-axis assembly / Z-motor mount. I had some 13" 8mm smooth rods lying around, so I based it off that. You can just as easily use threaded 5/16" rod you can grab at any big box store on the cheap.

First use 2 Gantry-Rod Connectors to attach the rods to the gantry. You'll need a few longer bolts (3" x 4) than stock MPCNC for mounting the rod clamps to the XY gantry parts.
Insert Rods thru the connectors.
Next attach the skirt to the Shoe Base with 3mm screws.
Attach that to the bottom of the rods.
I would like to use some sort of flexible clear material for the skirt, but for now I'm just printing the full skirt to ensure the dust is contained.
Next attach the Smooth Rod Top to the top of the rods. This also provides direction/control for hoses and wires.

Updates

12/11/17: Clarified longer bolts to be used to attach to gantry
10/23/17: Switched to Set-Screw type clamping (instead of friction)

author: ryanonmsn

description.text:
Made these around the same time I made the V1's, just never got around to posting it on here. I used a different key cap so they're easier to just print and stick onto the cherry mx switches and they're also more square-ish if that makes any sense. Changed the orientation of the guns on a few, and came up with a few new ones for leaning Left/Right, the fist for loot, cross for First Aid/Bandages, and the mountain-ish one for the map key. Still trying to fine tune my settings in cura to get less of that "stringy look." It's a learning process for sure.

NOTE:
In case you print one out and you find that they are too tall for your keyboard since mine stuck out like a mofo, the file "PUBGKeys Test.stl" has all the key caps in one file and they're a bit shorter in height.

From Original post:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2454396

After seeing CastleSeven's frying pad idea, I thought it would be pretty awesome to have keys for the other keys that are used in PUBG. Not sure if they really help or not but they look cool at least. Imo.

I don't think you really need supports inside the little stem as they are a pain in the ass to remove (I actually had to stick a metal screwdriver after heating it up and pretty much melt the inside of the stem a bit and then force them on to the switch so it forms around the cross + and once it cools it would hold the shape), but supports on just the inner cavity {Around the stem) would be ideal.

Next time I'm gonna try using a "clearish" PLA so the light from my keyboard would show through a bit. Will update will pictures if I ever do get to that.

Used the blank cherry MX keycap by eychu -
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:352885

Frying Pan keycap stl can be found here by CastleSeven- https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2443304

remixed_from.author: PrintPiet
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 (Jan.2017) NO SCREWS NEEDED - Prusa i3 MK8 EXTRUDER LED LIGHT

title: Anet A8 Screwless Extruder Light with LED Strip

description.text:
Original design by Printpiet.
I redesigned the mount in Tinkercad to accommodate pieces of a regular led strip and keep the screwless mounting method.

  • Tools:
    3D printer
    Hot glue gun
    Soldering iron

  • Materials:
    Filament
    Hot glue stick(s)
    Solder
    Wire (something like 0.2 mm2 or 24 AWG should be fine)
    LED strip (see the post-printing section)
    Optional: switch

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Should be printed with te side were wou would mount the led strip downwards.
I printed it in PLA which isn't generating any problems due to heat yet.

I recconment getting a 12V led strip because this is already avalible on the printer.

I bought the following LED strip discounted at €1.71, these aren't the best quality but they are cheap and work fine.
https://www.banggood.com/5M-White-3528-SMD-LED-Strip-Light-Non-Waterproof-12V-DC-300-LED-p-77079.html

  • Step one:
    Test-fit the printed part before you put any more work into it.
  • Step two:
    For this project we cut off 4 pieces of 3 LED and lay orientate them in the way you would mount them. Then wiring is very simple, just solder some jumpers from the - to the - and the + to the +. Be careful soldering the led strip mentioned above, the connections are thin and fragile. Also keep in mind to let the power wires heave enough slack for the printer to move.
  • Step three:
    Test if the LED's are working, in the case you use the same led strip connect the power wires to a 12 volts supply.
  • Step four:
    For mounting I recommend using hot glue to stick the piece of led strip, because of the heat generated by the hotend the self-sticking back will get loose.
    Isolate the connections the prevent possible shorts, I used some hotglue and heat shrink.
  • Step five:
    Mount the extruder light to your printer, connect to the power supply and now you can finally see what you are printing.

description.text: chick

author: yuh1973

description.text:
A box to travel with my oralB electric toothbrush head. There is a few issue in the top part where I did the zero wrongly before cutting the outer part of the top box. Nevermind, quite happy for my first object milled with my new shapeoko2. :) Designed in inventor fusion
Milled with shapeoko 2 in 18.2mm fir wood
Camed with MeshCam
1/8" end mill flute
feed rate : 300 mm/min - 2mm depth for roughing 150 for finishing (could go faster)
spindle at max speed need a bit of rework after to take off a few mm of woods if you want both box to fit together. Should have add some space in between top and bottom part of the box in the design. I'll now know for next project.
